values.title: [Gazebo9] Video Plugin Crashes Gzserver

content.raw:
Hello all,

It seems that the video plugin `libgazebo_ros_video.so` is crashing gzserver everytime I load it in ROS Kinetic + Gazebo 9. 

This is the code snippet:
``` <gazebo reference="screen">

    <visual>

      <plugin name="screen_video_controller" filename="libgazebo_ros_video.so">

        <height>600</height>

        <width>1024</width>

        <topicName>/robot/head_display</topicName>

        <robotNamespace>/robot</robotNamespace>

      </plugin>

    </visual>

  </gazebo>
```

If I try to load this model, I'll get:
```[ INFO] [1533119655.853751756]: GazeboRosVideo (gzclient, ns = /robot) has started

Segmentation fault (core dumped)

[gazebo_gui-3] process has died [pid 12932, exit code 139, cmd /opt/ros/kinetic/lib/gazebo_ros/gzclient __name:=gazebo_gui __log:=/home/arif/.ros/log/6157ef48-9576-11e8-90e1-6c71d97cbaff/gazebo_gui-3.log].
log file: /home/arif/.ros/log/6157ef48-9576-11e8-90e1-6c71d97cbaff/gazebo_gui-3*.log
```

But if I comment out that part, it loads ok (without that video display, of course). 

I understand that in Gazebo 7 it was outputting a warning #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2202/gazebo7-visualplugins-are-deprecated , but in my Gazebo 9 it just crashes. 

Can anyone help?

Can anyone help?

values.title: Trouble With The Actor based on the tutorial

content.raw:
I have been trying to experiment with actors in Gazebo to create scripted animations.
I have been following the tutorial on the Gazebosim homepage
http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=actor&cat=build_robo

I get do not get the expected behavior if I add any other component that is in contact with the physics engine and I use the <script> tag.
For the cube I stop and then suddenly jumps position like I previously reported here:
#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2482/actor-and-lidar-sensor-problems

For the walking person, he appears halfway through the ground-plane and moves with his arms stretched out. If I remove the  <script> tag from the waling actor everything seems to work as intended. 

Is there some way I can debug, this problem to provide are a more clear report ?

I am running ubuntu 18.04.1 and Gazebo 9.0.0

values.title: SetAxis implementation incorrect for DART

content.raw:
While trying to get a better understanding of the reference frame for joint axes in SDF, I noticed that the implementation of `SetAxis()` for `DARTHingeJoint` has a bug. Specifically, [this line](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/1561a52d5a7ca26980b3555800fe72c9038743c5/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTHingeJoint.cc#lines-120) shouldn't be in there. That transforms the joint axis into the parent link frame, but we just want it to be expressed in the frame that it's already in.

It seems this has gone unnoticed because that transform from the parent link frame is set to an identity matrix at the point in time that this function is called by the SDF loading routine, so it has no effect. However, if a user calls this function later, after the whole SDF has been loaded, then the axis will be set incorrectly if there's any relative rotation between the parent link and joint poses.

I already have a fix and regression test written for this. I'm opening this issue so that I can tag the regression test with an issue number.
content.html:
While trying to get a better understanding of the reference frame for joint axes in SDF, I noticed that the implementation of SetAxis() for DARTHingeJoint has a bug. Specifically, this line shouldn't be in there. That transforms the joint axis into the parent link frame, but we just want it to be expressed in the frame that it's already in.

It seems this has gone unnoticed because that transform from the parent link frame is set to an identity matrix at the point in time that this function is called by the SDF loading routine, so it has no effect. However, if a user calls this function later, after the whole SDF has been loaded, then the axis will be set incorrectly if there's any relative rotation between the parent link and joint poses.

I already have a fix and regression test written for this. I'm opening this issue so that I can tag the regression test with an issue number.

values.title: Bullet heightmap transform is wrong

content.raw:
Collision with heightmaps in Bullet is not working properly at the moment. The terrain is not at the right transform.

I think this is due to the [MotionState::setWorldTransform() in BulletHeightmapShape](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/src/00e746ff2fc08ad46d2641475b29ddd8b2a10803/gazebo/physics/bullet/BulletHeightmapShape.cc#lines-108) (see comment in linked line) not actually doing anything with the parameter (bullet’s terrain has to be translated, see also comment in [btHeightfieldTerrainShape](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/ab4b6638002c86d7d0c5d4a1b8e5728a227a92e3/src/BulletCollision/CollisionShapes/btHeightfieldTerrainShape.h#L44)).

This relates to pull request #2956 in which  I’ve added a heightmap test and some test worlds. I have added a branch named [bullet_heightmap_transform_error](https://bitbucket.org/JenniferBuehler/gazebo/src/bullet_heightmap_transform_error/) which basically includes all changes of pull request #2956, with the exception that the TerrainCollision test is **not** skipped for bullet, so that it can be shown that this new test fails.
content.html:
Collision with heightmaps in Bullet is not working properly at the moment. The terrain is not at the right transform.

I think this is due to the MotionState::setWorldTransform() in BulletHeightmapShape (see comment in linked line) not actually doing anything with the parameter (bullet’s terrain has to be translated, see also comment in btHeightfieldTerrainShape).

This relates to pull request #2956 in which I’ve added a heightmap test and some test worlds. I have added a branch named bullet_heightmap_transform_error which basically includes all changes of pull request #2956, with the exception that the TerrainCollision test is not skipped for bullet, so that it can be shown that this new test fails.

values.title: Joint::SetForce is not additive in Simbody

content.raw:
[`Joint::SetForce`](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1physics_1_1Joint.html#ab2491053d1c5ebb97c377064797af494) docs states that:

> Force is additive (multiple calls to SetForce to the same joint in the same time step will accumulate forces on that Joint). 

However, it seems that this is not true for the `simbody` physics engine, where instead every call to SetForce is overwriting the previous one, even if no update to the physics happened in the meanwhile.

Relevant code:

*  #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyHingeJoint.cc#lines-104 
* http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1physics_1_1SimbodyJoint.html#ad530d5fed74a854064dc377c3df166cd 
* https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/3.5/classSimTK_1_1Force_1_1DiscreteForces.html#a96a4c79e1209de2053a1508cd0b8264d 

Downstream issue: https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-fmi/issues/4

Similar issue, but related to DART: #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2526/joint-setforce-is-not-additive-in-dart-in .
content.html:
Joint::SetForce docs states that:

Force is additive (multiple calls to SetForce to the same joint in the same time step will accumulate forces on that Joint).

However, it seems that this is not true for the simbody physics engine, where instead every call to SetForce is overwriting the previous one, even if no update to the physics happened in the meanwhile.

Relevant code:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/physics/simbody/SimbodyHingeJoint.cc#lines-104
  • http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1physics_1_1SimbodyJoint.html#ad530d5fed74a854064dc377c3df166cd
  • https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/3.5/classSimTK_1_1Force_1_1DiscreteForces.html#a96a4c79e1209de2053a1508cd0b8264d

Downstream issue: https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-fmi/issues/4

Similar issue, but related to DART: #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2526/joint-setforce-is-not-additive-in-dart-in .

values.title: Unable to toggle light visual

content.raw: There is currently no way to turn off the visual representation of the light (i.e. the green lines). Calling functions in the Light class, e.g. `ToggleVisual` and `ShowVisual`, affects the light itself, e.g. `ShowVisual(false)` turns the light off completely
content.html: There is currently no way to turn off the visual representation of the light (i.e. the green lines). Calling functions in the Light class, e.g. ToggleVisual and ShowVisual, affects the light itself, e.g. ShowVisual(false) turns the light off completely

values.title: Running physics::World step-wise

content.html:
It would be nice to have a clean way to run the physics::World step-wise. So not starting a thread as it's done by calling physics::World::Run(), but instead completely control the loop from outside World.

Let's say we have a externalLoop() function in which we would like to update the world

void externalLoop(gazebo::physics::WorldPtr &world)
{
  // do initializations
  /* ... */

  while (/* something */)
  {
       // do one update step for world
      /* ... */
   }
}

There are currently two options, unless I'm missing some, each of which has drawbacks (discussed below).

Option 1

Call world->RunBlocking(1) with one iteration (or use gazebo::runWorld() which just calls World::RunBlocking()). This will cause a call to World::RunLoop().

  // do initializations
  /* nothing required here */

  while (/* something */)
  {
       // do one update step for world
     world->RunBlocking(1);
   }

This comes with the pretty big flaw that because World::RunLoop is called repeatedly, the iterations, start time etc. are reset each time. However we would actually just like to World::Step() in our loop, and not make a whole run with just one iteration.

Option 2

In the initialization step, first pause the world and then run it indefinitely (passing 0 as iterations). Inside the loop, then use World::Step(1).
Running the world in paused mode will then not update the world (so not calling World::Update or increase iterations), it will just keep doing other stuff like publishing world stats. Then, in the loop, we can call world->Step(1) which sets World::stepInc to the desired iterations, and therefore the World thread will actually update the world in its next iteration(s).

  // do initializations
  world->SetPaused(true);
  world->RunLoop(0);

  while (/* something */)
  {
       // do one update step for world
      world->Step(1);
   }

This achieves the desired behavior, because World::Step(int) waits for the World thread to actually have done the steps. However technically the world updating is still running from a separate thread. It would be nice to just call World::Step() (the version without in parameter) from within our loop.

Improved version?

It would be nice to be able to use an improved version of Option (2), but it would require modifications to World.

One option would be to split World::RunLoop into three parts: (1) the pre-loop code, and maybe call it InitExplicitRun() (2) the loop part, maybe call it RunWorldSteps (this can remain private) and (3) the post-loop part, maybe call it FinishExplicitRun().

Something like this (have not tested code, just to scetch the idea):

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void World::RunLoop()
{
     InitExplicitRun();
     RunWorldSteps();
     FinishExplicitRun();
}

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void World::InitExplicitRun()
{
  this->dataPtr->physicsEngine->InitForThread();

  this->dataPtr->startTime = common::Time::GetWallTime();

  // This fixes a minor issue when the world is paused before it's started
  if (this->IsPaused())
    this->dataPtr->pauseStartTime = this->dataPtr->startTime;

  this->dataPtr->prevStepWallTime = common::Time::GetWallTime();

  // Get the first state
  this->dataPtr->prevStates[0] = WorldState(shared_from_this());
  this->dataPtr->prevStates[1] = WorldState(shared_from_this());
  this->dataPtr->stateToggle = 0;

  this->dataPtr->logThread =
    new std::thread(std::bind(&World::LogWorker, this));

  // reset iterations
  this->dataPtr->iterations = 0;

  // disable physics engine, in case we do not use the internal
  // run thread which calls RunWorldSteps() in which this is done.
  if (util::LogPlay::Instance()->IsOpen())
  {
    this->dataPtr->enablePhysicsEngine = false;
   }
}

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void World::RunWorldSteps()
{
  if (!util::LogPlay::Instance()->IsOpen())
  {
    for (this->dataPtr->iterations = 0; !this->dataPtr->stop &&
        (!this->dataPtr->stopIterations ||
         (this->dataPtr->iterations < this->dataPtr->stopIterations));)
    {
      this->Step();
    }
  }
  else
  {
    this->dataPtr->enablePhysicsEngine = false;
    for (this->dataPtr->iterations = 0; !this->dataPtr->stop &&
        (!this->dataPtr->stopIterations ||
         (this->dataPtr->iterations < this->dataPtr->stopIterations));)
    {
      this->LogStep();
    }
  }
}

//////////////////////////////////////////////////
void World::FinishExplicitRun()
{
  this->dataPtr->stop = true;

  if (this->dataPtr->logThread)
  {
    this->dataPtr->logCondition.notify_all();
    {
      std::lock_guard<std::mutex> lock(this->dataPtr->logMutex);
      this->dataPtr->logCondition.notify_all();
    }
    this->dataPtr->logThread->join();
    delete this->dataPtr->logThread;
    this->dataPtr->logThread = nullptr;
  }
}

If we had it like that, we could do the following in our loop:

void externalLoop(gazebo::physics::WorldPtr &world)
{
  // do initializations
  world->InitExplicitRun();

  while (/* something */)
  {
       // do one update step for world
      world->Step(1);
   }
  world->FinishExplicitRun();
}

This would be much cleaner. However it comes with the disadvantage of exposing two new public functions in World: InitExplicitRun() and FinishExplicitRun(). Also, minor modifications in World::Step(int) would be required to directly call World::Step() (without the wait) in case the World thread is not running.

Altogether this could be changes which are acceptable IMO, considering that it would allow better control of the loop from outside... but it does require modifications in World which I understand is a big thing.

Anyway, question: Would you be open to such changes? Or is it better to just use either of the existing options, even if not perfect?

If you're open to the changes, I'm happy to post a PR including tests.

values.title: Bug in URDF to SDF convertion for Boolean tags in Gazebo 9

content.raw:
When load robot URDF to gazebo Boolean values in <plugin> tag are converted to Integers

Part of input URDF:
```
#!xml
  <gazebo>
    <plugin filename="libgazebo_ros_diff_drive.so" name="pioneer_lx_differential_drive_controller">
      <alwaysOn>true</alwaysOn>
      <updateRate>100</updateRate>
      <leftJoint>pioneer_lx_l_wheel_joint</leftJoint>
      <rightJoint>pioneer_lx_r_wheel_joint</rightJoint>
      <robotBaseFrame>pioneer_lx_base_link</robotBaseFrame>
      <wheelSeparation>0.4</wheelSeparation>
      <wheelDiameter>0.2</wheelDiameter>
      <wheelTorque>25</wheelTorque>
      <wheelAcceleration>0</wheelAcceleration>
      <legacyMode>false</legacyMode>
    </plugin>
  </gazebo>

```

Loading to gazebo yields warnings "<tag_name> must be either true or false"
and values are not loaded.


Part of resulting SDF:

```
#!xml

    <plugin name='pioneer_lx_differential_drive_controller' filename='libgazebo_ros_diff_drive.so'>
      <alwaysOn>1</alwaysOn>
      <updateRate>100</updateRate>
      <leftJoint>pioneer_lx_l_wheel_joint</leftJoint>
      <rightJoint>pioneer_lx_r_wheel_joint</rightJoint>
      <robotBaseFrame>pioneer_lx_base_link</robotBaseFrame>
      <wheelSeparation>0.4</wheelSeparation>
      <wheelDiameter>0.2</wheelDiameter>
      <wheelTorque>25</wheelTorque>
      <wheelAcceleration>0</wheelAcceleration>
      <legacyMode>0</legacyMode>
    </plugin>

```
content.html:
When load robot URDF to gazebo Boolean values in <plugin> tag are converted to Integers

values.title: Error when retrieving noise type that sensor doesn't have specified

content.raw:
If I have an imu sensor with no noise specified in the SDF, when I go to call e.g. `sensor->Noise(gazebo::sensors::SensorNoiseType::IMU_LINACC_X_NOISE_METERS_PER_S_SQR)`, I'm seeing "Get noise index not valid" errors printed from here: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/gazebo/sensors/Sensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Sensor.cc-454.

(context: https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/793/files#r211036103)


Which of the following would be most appropriate?

1. remove that error message (most straightforward, but it's up to the caller to know that their request is a valid one).
1. always set the relevant noise models [when initialising the sensor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ImuSensor.cc-156), defaulting to no noise.
1. add a method to check if the sensor has that noise model, which should be called before  calling `sensor->Noise()`
content.html:
If I have an imu sensor with no noise specified in the SDF, when I go to call e.g. sensor->Noise(gazebo::sensors::SensorNoiseType::IMU_LINACC_X_NOISE_METERS_PER_S_SQR), I'm seeing "Get noise index not valid" errors printed from here: #!/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/gazebo/sensors/Sensor.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Sensor.cc-454.

(context: https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/pull/793/files#r211036103)

Which of the following would be most appropriate?

  1. remove that error message (most straightforward, but it's up to the caller to know that their request is a valid one).
  2. always set the relevant noise models when initialising the sensor, defaulting to no noise.
  3. add a method to check if the sensor has that noise model, which should be called before calling sensor->Noise()

values.title: Gazebo 7 rotations broken between 7.0.0+dfsg-2 and 7.14.0-1~xenial

content.raw:
We are working with Gazebo 7 on Ubuntu 16.04 and ROS Kinetic.  When using release 7.0.0+dfsg-2, we could rotate our custom robot smoothly either with a joytstick or by sending Twist commands.  When we updated to release 7.14.0-1~xenial, rotations became horribly broken as you can see in [this video](https://youtu.be/kNZLOSvELg8) and [this video](https://youtu.be/wgqgdksxaQ4).  (The first video has the case on the robot and the second video is without the case.  Both behaviors are the same.)  In both videos, we are publishing a simple Twist message on /cmd_vel that has 0.1 in the angular.z component and 0 everywhere else.

We really need to get back to the previous behavior which was pure rotation around the vertical axis.
content.html:
We are working with Gazebo 7 on Ubuntu 16.04 and ROS Kinetic. When using release 7.0.0+dfsg-2, we could rotate our custom robot smoothly either with a joytstick or by sending Twist commands. When we updated to release 7.14.0-1~xenial, rotations became horribly broken as you can see in this video and this video. (The first video has the case on the robot and the second video is without the case. Both behaviors are the same.) In both videos, we are publishing a simple Twist message on /cmd_vel that has 0.1 in the angular.z component and 0 everywhere else.

We really need to get back to the previous behavior which was pure rotation around the vertical axis.

values.title: Joint::SetForce is not additive in DART in Gazebo 9

content.raw:
[`Joint::SetForce`](http://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/gazebo/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1physics_1_1Joint.html#ab2491053d1c5ebb97c377064797af494) documentation states that:

> Force is additive (multiple calls to SetForce to the same joint in the same time step will accumulate forces on that Joint). 

However, it seems that this is not true for the `DART` physics engine, where instead every call to SetForce is overwriting the previous one, even if no update to the physics happened in the meanwhile.

Relevant code:

*  #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTJoint.cc#lines-839
* https://dartsim.github.io/api/v6.3.0/d6/d5b/classdart_1_1dynamics_1_1Joint.html#a7fb4ae07eeb286f050722d982309e1a0

Downstream issue: https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-fmi/pull/28 
Similar issue, but related to Simbody: #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2507/joint-setforce-is-not-additive-in-simbody .
content.html:
Joint::SetForce documentation states that:

Force is additive (multiple calls to SetForce to the same joint in the same time step will accumulate forces on that Joint).

However, it seems that this is not true for the DART physics engine, where instead every call to SetForce is overwriting the previous one, even if no update to the physics happened in the meanwhile.

Relevant code:

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/src/01c7f8b1d68448bc618b575ad1c7ec13fee2b87f/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTJoint.cc#lines-839
  • https://dartsim.github.io/api/v6.3.0/d6/d5b/classdart_1_1dynamics_1_1Joint.html#a7fb4ae07eeb286f050722d982309e1a0

Downstream issue: https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-fmi/pull/28 Similar issue, but related to Simbody: #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2507/joint-setforce-is-not-additive-in-simbody .

values.title: Last camera's distortion affects previous cameras' distortions

content.raw:
See the following world for example, where the first camera appears to have barrel distortion even though it was supposed to be pincushion. Swapping the order of models in the world makes both cameras be pincushion.

~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.6">
  <world name="default">

    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>

    <model name="ground_plane">
      <static>true</static>
      <link name="link">
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <plane>
              <normal>0 0 1</normal>
              <size>100 100</size>
            </plane>
          </geometry>
          <surface>
            <friction>
              <ode>
                <mu>100</mu>
                <mu2>50</mu2>
              </ode>
            </friction>
              <bounce>
                <restitution_coefficient>1.0</restitution_coefficient>
                <threshold>0</threshold>
              </bounce>
              <contact>
                <ode>
                  <max_vel>10000</max_vel>
                  <min_depth>0.001</min_depth>
                </ode>
              </contact>
          </surface>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <cast_shadows>false</cast_shadows>
          <geometry>
            <plane>
              <normal>0 0 1</normal>
              <size>100 100</size>
            </plane>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <script>
              <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
              <name>Gazebo/Grey</name>
            </script>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>

    <model name="ball">
      <allow_auto_disable>false</allow_auto_disable>
      <pose>-1 0 1 0 0 0</pose>
      <static>false</static>
      <link name="link">
        <inertial>
          <mass>0.026</mass>
          <!-- inertia based on solid sphere 2/5 mr^2 -->
          <inertia>
            <ixx>1.664e-5</ixx>
            <iyy>1.664e-5</iyy>
            <izz>1.664e-5</izz>
            <ixy>0</ixy>
            <ixz>0</ixz>
            <iyz>0</iyz>
          </inertia>
        </inertial>
        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.04</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
          <surface>
            <bounce>
              <restitution_coefficient>1.0</restitution_coefficient>
              <threshold>0</threshold>
            </bounce>
            <contact>
              <ode>
                <max_vel>10000</max_vel>
                <min_depth>0.001</min_depth>
              </ode>
            </contact>
          </surface>
        </collision>
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.04</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>

    <model name="camera_pincushion">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 3.14</pose>
      <static>true</static>
      <link name="pincushion">
        <sensor type="camera" name="camera_pincushion">
          <update_rate>60</update_rate>
          <visualize>true</visualize>
          <camera name="head">
            <horizontal_fov>0.927295218</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>640</width>
              <height>480</height>
              <format>R8G8B8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>300</far>
            </clip>
            <distortion>
              <k1>0.1</k1>
              <k2>0.1</k2>
              <p1>0</p1>
              <p2>0</p2>
              <k3>0.1</k3>
              <center>0.5 0.5</center>
            </distortion>
          </camera>
        </sensor>
      </link>
    </model>

    <model name="camera_barrel">
      <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 3.14</pose>
      <static>true</static>
      <link name="barrel">
        <sensor type="camera" name="camera_barrel">
          <update_rate>60</update_rate>
          <visualize>true</visualize>
          <camera name="head">
            <horizontal_fov>0.927295218</horizontal_fov>
            <image>
              <width>640</width>
              <height>480</height>
              <format>R8G8B8</format>
            </image>
            <clip>
              <near>0.02</near>
              <far>300</far>
            </clip>
            <distortion>
              <k1>-0.1</k1>
              <k2>-0.1</k2>
              <p1>0</p1>
              <p2>0</p2>
              <k3>-0.1</k3>
              <center>0.5 0.5</center>
            </distortion>
          </camera>
        </sensor>
      </link>
    </model>

    <include>
      <pose>-1.5 0 1 0 1.57 0</pose>
      <uri>model://checkerboard_plane</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>
~~~

              <p2>0</p2>
              <k3>-0.1</k3>
              <center>0.5 0.5</center>
            </distortion>
          </camera>
        </sensor>
      </link>
    </model>

    <include>
      <pose>-1.5 0 1 0 1.57 0</pose>
      <uri>model://checkerboard_plane</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

values.title: Issue with the post grasp motion with the gripper in Gazebo 7.12.0

content.raw:
Hello,

I have been facing issue with my robot after grasping an object. The problem is that everything seems good until it grasps the object. Once the object is grasped, when the arm is doing some kind of motion, then the gripper links tend to open and close during the motion, thereby releasing the grasp object. I tried may ways thinking its a controller issue, by tuning the PID, increasing the mass, collision mesh and many more. The end results are almost same, no improvement in any case.  Even the grasp hack which has been used earlier has also been tested, but still no use. The same configuration of the robot worked fine in gazebo version 2.2.3. Any idea how to fix the issue.

![gripper info during grasping](https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/RLq61-UqOZ8jmcHtv6eaKSASOXrXg9Z919dYYxY-lncFHpvZimGzkK3qCCy2VAByDgZOFy-pj_tYUayLAFR3VTa5Kj1Bq-JihsVVelqZ)

values.title: Links moving/rotating at startup when they are in a chain of fixed joints using bullet physics

content.raw:
When there are two or more links attached to a base link through fixed type joints AND the orientation of one of those child links is near [pi 0 0] or [0 0 pi], as declared in the <pose> of the sdf, they move in the first iterations. This happens only when using bullet as the physics type.

test.world :

```
#!xml
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <world name='bug_world'>
    <physics type='bullet'>
    </physics>

    <gravity>0 0 0</gravity>

    <model name="model">
        <include>
            <name>test</name>
            <uri>model://test</uri>
        </include>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

```

model.sdf :

```
#!xml

<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <model name='test'>

    <link name='base'>
      <gravity>0</gravity>
    </link>
    
    <link name='ins1_frame'>
      <gravity>0</gravity>
      <pose>0 0.1 0 0 0 0</pose>
      <visual name='ins1_visual'>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
              <uri>model://test/meshes/sensors/ins.dae</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
    </link>

    <link name='ins2_frame'>
      <gravity>0</gravity>
      <pose>0 -0.1 0 3.14159 0 0</pose>
      <visual name='ins2_visual'>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
              <uri>model://test/meshes/sensors/ins.dae</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
    </link>

    <joint name='ins1_joint' type='fixed'>
      <parent>base</parent>
      <child>ins1_frame</child>
    </joint>

    <joint name='ins2_joint' type='fixed'>
      <parent>base</parent>
      <child>ins2_frame</child>
    </joint>
    
  </model>
</sdf>
```

Result:
![bug.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1553944858-bug.gif)

When the pose is not <pose>X Y Z 3.14159 0 0</pose> but <pose>X Y Z 3.14 0 0</pose>, for example, things work normally. I'm running Gazebo 8.6.0, didn't test the bug in Gazebo 9.

values.title: Scene Properties: Gazebo plugins don't work with a max step size of less than 1 millisecond

content.raw:
I had serious issues when I simulated the behavior of a drone in Gazebo with a max step size of less than 1 millisecond: the odometry plugin returns something strange. When I apply a constant thrust (all the propellers have the same speed) the linear velocity (I use the odometry plugin to measure it) increases its value up to 0.025 m/s. Reached, the linear velocity does not increase even if the position along the same axis continue to rise. Therefore, the data come out from the sensor.
I think such problem should be the same with any object in the virtual reality environment.

I tried to reduce and increase the update rate, varying also the real-time factor and the number of iterations, but the plugin does not work when the sampling time is less than 1 millisecond. 

I'm using [RotorS](https://github.com/ethz-asl/rotors_simulator), a famous Micro Aerial Vehicles simulator developed by ETH Zurich. 

I can attach a video if it can help in some way to understand what happens.

values.title: Update gazebo8_ros_pkgs to fix ABI breakage on diff drive plugin

content.raw:
@iche033 reported problems with receiving `TF_OLD_DATA` errors produced by the `gazebo_ros_diff_drive plugin`. The underlying root cause is the [ABI breakable in rostime](https://github.com/ros/roscpp_core/pull/82).

I'm going to rebuild the unofficial `gazebo8_ros_pkgs` for Kinetic what will bring the latest features and bug fixes to them. The Kinetic version will jump from `2.5.14-2` to `2.5.17-1`. The changelogs are available in the upstream repository:

 * [gazebo_plugins changelog](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_plugins/CHANGELOG.rst)
 * [gazebo_ros changelog](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_ros/CHANGELOG.rst)
 * [gazebo_ros_control changelog](https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs/blob/kinetic-devel/gazebo_ros_control/CHANGELOG.rst)

I'm also releasing Lunar from `2.7.2-1`to `2.7.6-0.
content.html:
@iche033 reported problems with receiving TF_OLD_DATA errors produced by the gazebo_ros_diff_drive plugin. The underlying root cause is the ABI breakable in rostime.

I'm going to rebuild the unofficial gazebo8_ros_pkgs for Kinetic what will bring the latest features and bug fixes to them. The Kinetic version will jump from 2.5.14-2 to 2.5.17-1. The changelogs are available in the upstream repository:

  • gazebo_plugins changelog
  • gazebo_ros changelog
  • gazebo_ros_control changelog

I'm also releasing Lunar from 2.7.2-1to `2.7.6-0.

values.title: GUI Plugins failed to load

content.raw:
Hello,

We have got some issues with the GUI plugins tutorials: [Link Text](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=gui_overlay)

We have to precise that we followed the tutorial meticulously and we didn’t skip any step.

Every time we try to start gazebo with any kind of GUI plugins we receive this type of error message:

    [Err] [Plugin.hh:180] Failed to load plugin /usr/local/lib/libgui_example_spawn_widget.so: /usr/local/lib/libgui_example_spawn_widget.so: undefined symbol: _ZN5QTest18lastMouseTimestampE
    [Err] [RenderWidget.cc:311] Unable to create gui overlay plugin with filename[libgui_example_spawn_widget.so]

We have of course added the plugin path into `GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH`. 

Moreover, we have tried to run gui plugin with the `~/.gazebo/gui.ini` or through a sdf file or with the command `gzclient –gui-client-plugin`. We always have the same issue. 

This issue occurred only with the GUI plugins, we didn’t have any problems with other type of plugin.
 
We are working with Gazebo 9.4.1 on Ubuntu 18.0.4 

Do you have some idea how can we fix this issue ?

values.title: Setting up camera to track object in world file messes up manual camera motion

content.raw:
When setting up the camera to start up tracking an object in a world file, e.g.

```
#!

      <camera name='user_camera'>
        <pose>-3.89585 1.64044 3.3274 0 0.407643 -0.482987</pose>
        <view_controller>orbit</view_controller>
        <track_visual>
          <name>robot_description</name>
          <min_dist>1.0</min_dist>
          <max_dist>2.5</max_dist>
          <static>true</static>
          <use_model_frame>true</use_model_frame>
          <xyz>0.2 5 4.2</xyz>
        </track_visual>
      </camera>
```
and then pressing `Esc` to leave tracking/follow mode, manual controls of the camera are messed up and not working as they should (camera is rolling instead of rotating about orbit target point, translation seems to go into random directions).

This is on 16.04/Kinetic from .debs/Gazebo9 from .debs.

values.title: Gazebo GUI Position PID controller Integrated term not cleared when world reset

content.raw:
Tested on Ubuntu Bionic with Gazebo 9.4.1


1. Launch Gazebo
1. Insert the model "Simple Arm"
1. Select the inserted model in the render window
1. Drag the bar on the right of the gazebo GUI render window to expose the joint pane
1. For the joint "arm_shoulder_pan_joint" in the Position tab enter a target of 0 with PID gains (0, 10, 0)
1. Pause the world, change the target to 1.5
1. Unpause the world. Wait for the arm to move 45 degrees then pause the world again.
1. set the target position to 0 again. reset the world with `Ctrl + r` and then unpause it

The expected behavior is the model should not move when the world is unpaused because the model is already at the target position (0) and the controllers should be reset with the world. The actual behavior is the model starts moving after world reset, which may be caused by the integrated error not being cleared by the world reset.
content.html:
Tested on Ubuntu Bionic with Gazebo 9.4.1

  1. Launch Gazebo
  2. Insert the model "Simple Arm"
  3. Select the inserted model in the render window
  4. Drag the bar on the right of the gazebo GUI render window to expose the joint pane
  5. For the joint "arm_shoulder_pan_joint" in the Position tab enter a target of 0 with PID gains (0, 10, 0)
  6. Pause the world, change the target to 1.5
  7. Unpause the world. Wait for the arm to move 45 degrees then pause the world again.
  8. set the target position to 0 again. reset the world with Ctrl + r and then unpause it

The expected behavior is the model should not move when the world is unpaused because the model is already at the target position (0) and the controllers should be reset with the world. The actual behavior is the model starts moving after world reset, which may be caused by the integrated error not being cleared by the world reset.

values.title: Too large values for explicit joint damping can cause models to fly apart

content.raw:
The [<damping>](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=joint#dynamics_damping) tag applies a force depending on the velocity of the joint. If this value is too large the force will result in a new velocity that's greater than the previous timestep in the opposite direction, which oscillates until the model flies apart.

It would be nice if explicit damping would cap the force applied to the amount needed to stop joint movement, though I'm not sure how feasible getting that number is.
content.html:
The <damping> tag applies a force depending on the velocity of the joint. If this value is too large the force will result in a new velocity that's greater than the previous timestep in the opposite direction, which oscillates until the model flies apart.

It would be nice if explicit damping would cap the force applied to the amount needed to stop joint movement, though I'm not sure how feasible getting that number is.

values.title: gzclient crash "minimum cornder of box must be less than..." when positions NaN

content.raw:
1. Start the attached world paused `gazebo --pause tmp_collapse.world`
1. When the client starts, unpause the world

The gazebo GUI will crash with the following error.

```
gzclient: /build/ogre-1.9-mqY1wq/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.
```

This happens because the posotion of an object becomes `NaN`. Either it should be caught before it's sent to the client, or the client should check values for `NaN` before using them.
content.html:
1. Start the attached world paused gazebo --pause tmp_collapse.world
  2. When the client starts, unpause the world

The gazebo GUI will crash with the following error.

gzclient: /build/ogre-1.9-mqY1wq/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/include/OgreAxisAlignedBox.h:252: void Ogre::AxisAlignedBox::setExtents(const Ogre::Vector3&, const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `(min.x <= max.x && min.y <= max.y && min.z <= max.z) && "The minimum corner of the box must be less than or equal to maximum corner"' failed.

This happens because the posotion of an object becomes NaN. Either it should be caught before it's sent to the client, or the client should check values for NaN before using them.

values.title: Simulated camera framerate slow down and latency increase when subscribing to multiple cameras

content.raw:
This is on Ubuntu 16.04/Kinetic/Gazebo9 from .debs.

I have a fairly complex world (which I unfortunately cannot share) and a (ROS-based) robot with 4 cameras (using `libgazebo_ros_camera`) moving inside it.

As long as I only subscribe to the image of one of the cameras, everything largely works fine. I get a realtime factor of ~0.95, images come in at a rate of 10Hz (as specified). When subscribing to the images of the three other cameras, the following effects are observed:

* Realtime factor stays relatively consistent at about ~0.8.
* The latency of images increases greatly. When comparing image timestamps to `ros::Time::now()` inside a ROS image callback, the delay is about 1 (simulated) second.
* The publishing rate of the original image drops dramatically from 10 Hz (as specified) to about 4.0 Hz.

It thus looks like rendering images takes considerable time. That's ok in principle, but what I'd expect in that case is that Gazebo slows down accordingly to keep the image publishing rate. Is the observed behavior the intended/expected one?
content.html:
This is on Ubuntu 16.04/Kinetic/Gazebo9 from .debs.

I have a fairly complex world (which I unfortunately cannot share) and a (ROS-based) robot with 4 cameras (using libgazebo_ros_camera) moving inside it.

As long as I only subscribe to the image of one of the cameras, everything largely works fine. I get a realtime factor of ~0.95, images come in at a rate of 10Hz (as specified). When subscribing to the images of the three other cameras, the following effects are observed:

  • Realtime factor stays relatively consistent at about ~0.8.
  • The latency of images increases greatly. When comparing image timestamps to ros::Time::now() inside a ROS image callback, the delay is about 1 (simulated) second.
  • The publishing rate of the original image drops dramatically from 10 Hz (as specified) to about 4.0 Hz.

It thus looks like rendering images takes considerable time. That's ok in principle, but what I'd expect in that case is that Gazebo slows down accordingly to keep the image publishing rate. Is the observed behavior the intended/expected one?

values.title: gzclient often misses static entities' pose updates

content.raw:
When a static entity's pose is changed programmatically on the server, a single message is sent on the `~/pose/info` topic notifying gzclient. And due to the [60Hz update rate](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/gazebo/physics/World.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#World.cc-213), this message is often dropped.

This is not a problem for dynamic entities since they have more messages being published and eventually they reach the client.
content.html:
When a static entity's pose is changed programmatically on the server, a single message is sent on the ~/pose/info topic notifying gzclient. And due to the 60Hz update rate, this message is often dropped.

This is not a problem for dynamic entities since they have more messages being published and eventually they reach the client.

content.raw:
This line throws the exception:
```
(gdb) up
#5  gazebo::common::SystemPaths::UpdateModelPaths (this=0x80a88da90 <SingletonT<gazebo::common::SystemPaths>::GetInstance()::t>)
    at /usr/ports/misc/gazebo/work/osrf-gazebo-490bc3398435/gazebo/common/SystemPaths.cc:213
213	  this->InsertUnique(path.substr(pos1, path.size()-pos1), this->modelPaths);
```

```
(gdb) p pos1
$5 = 33
(gdb) p path.size()
$6 = 32
(gdb) p path.c_str()
$7 = (const std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >::value_type *) 0x829a2b190 "/usr/local/share/gazebo-9/models"
```

So the arithmetic there fails and causes the overflow and the negative size is supplied to the ```path.substr``` function.

values.title: Client fails to connect to the server because the server begins to listen only later

content.raw:
The boost error passed into ```Connection::OnConnect``` is ```system:61``` which is ```Connection refused```.

Kernel log shows that server begins to listen after this failure occurs.

No error is printed anywhere. The code loses boosts's error```system:61```.
UI comes up dysfunctional.

How is client supposed to synchronize with the server? You should first begin to listen, and then launch the client.

values.title: Static constructor catastrophe

content.raw:

```gazebo::common::SystemPaths::SystemPaths``` is being called from static constructors before ```PathDelimiter``` initialization.

Please move system initialization into the ```main``` function. Doing complex initializations from static constructors is a bad idea.

values.title: Support for self-describing messages

content.raw:
Hi,

It's a well known limitation (or implementation consideration) that Protocol Buffers do not contain descriptions of their own types. That happens to be a problem to Gazebo in the sense that we are not able to use the Gazebo tools without having to compile the code from source. Tools like `gztopic -e <topic>` do not work for new custom messages, as reported previously.

So, my question is: does Gazebo support self-describing messages? Is there any other considerations to take into account besides adding a `FileDescriptorSet` to the message definition? Does it require any change on the Gazebo GUI/tools so to be able to support these?

Thanks in advance for your feedback!
content.html:
Hi,

It's a well known limitation (or implementation consideration) that Protocol Buffers do not contain descriptions of their own types. That happens to be a problem to Gazebo in the sense that we are not able to use the Gazebo tools without having to compile the code from source. Tools like gztopic -e <topic> do not work for new custom messages, as reported previously.

So, my question is: does Gazebo support self-describing messages? Is there any other considerations to take into account besides adding a FileDescriptorSet to the message definition? Does it require any change on the Gazebo GUI/tools so to be able to support these?

Thanks in advance for your feedback!

values.title: Menu actions Already Tracked

content.html:
When starting gazebo, there seems to be an issue where the menus are being added/tracked more than once. (see below)

Replication: Running gazebo --verbose give the following messages.

[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:120] void DBusMenuExporterPrivate::addAction(QAction*, int): Already tracking action "&File" under id 48
[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:120] void DBusMenuExporterPrivate::addAction(QAction*, int): Already tracking action "&Edit" under id 51
[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:120] void DBusMenuExporterPrivate::addAction(QAction*, int): Already tracking action "&View" under id 53
[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:120] void DBusMenuExporterPrivate::addAction(QAction*, int): Already tracking action "&Window" under id 56
[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:120] void DBusMenuExporterPrivate::addAction(QAction*, int): Already tracking action "&Help" under id 60

I saw this in MainWindow.cc: 

void MainWindow::AddMenu(QMenu *_menu)
{
  if (!_menu)
    return;

  // Get the main window's menubar
  // Note: for some reason we can not call menuBar() again,
  // so manually retrieving the menubar from the mainwindow.
  QList<QMenuBar *> menuBars  = this->findChildren<QMenuBar *>();
  if (!menuBars.empty())
  {
    // Note: addMenu(QMenu *) works the first time but when
    // ShowMenuBar() is called more than once which results in menus being
    // re-added, (e.g. when switching between model editor and simulation modes)
    // _menu does not show up in the menu bar.
    // So workaround is to use addMenu(QString)
    QMenu *newMenu = menuBars[0]->addMenu(_menu->title());

    for (auto &menuAct : _menu->actions())
      newMenu->addAction(menuAct);
  }
}

values.title: Heightmap cache file is not created in Bionic

content.raw:
Gazebo 9.5 does not create a cache file when loading heightmaps in Ubuntu Bionic. 

To reproduce, run `gazebo heightmap_test.world`

In this example, a directory `~/.gazebo/paging/heightmap_bowl` and a file `gzterrain.SHA1` are created, but the cache file is missing. 

However, if I add the following material tag in the `visual` tag:
```
<material>
  <script>
    <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
    <name>Gazebo/White</name>
  </script>
</material>
```
The cache file is created, but then the heightmap won't have the right texture.
content.html:
Gazebo 9.5 does not create a cache file when loading heightmaps in Ubuntu Bionic.

To reproduce, run gazebo heightmap_test.world

In this example, a directory ~/.gazebo/paging/heightmap_bowl and a file gzterrain.SHA1 are created, but the cache file is missing.

However, if I add the following material tag in the visual tag:

<material>
  <script>
    <uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri>
    <name>Gazebo/White</name>
  </script>
</material>

The cache file is created, but then the heightmap won't have the right texture.

    <pose>0 0 0.035 0 0 0</pose>

</sdf>

values.title: boost signals library removed in boost 1.69

content.raw:
The boost signals library was deprecated in 1.54 in favor of the signals2 code, which is header-only. The signals library is removed in boost 1.69, which was just released and is being tested in homebrew:

* https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/35030

With boost 1.69, gazebo fails to find boost during configuration, as it searches for the signals component.

* #!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#SearchForStuff.cmake-603

I'm not sure when boost 1.69 will be merged into homebrew, but it will break gazebo on homebrew when it does. We should try to fix this before that is merged if possible. If an API/ABI compatible patch is not possible; we can consider maintaining a `boost@1.68` bottle in our tap, but I would really not want to do that.
content.html:
The boost signals library was deprecated in 1.54 in favor of the signals2 code, which is header-only. The signals library is removed in boost 1.69, which was just released and is being tested in homebrew:

  • https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/35030

With boost 1.69, gazebo fails to find boost during configuration, as it searches for the signals component.

  • #!/osrf/gazebo/src/0110572a49ba08936c9ac1972771db391b5ab721/cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#SearchForStuff.cmake-603

I'm not sure when boost 1.69 will be merged into homebrew, but it will break gazebo on homebrew when it does. We should try to fix this before that is merged if possible. If an API/ABI compatible patch is not possible; we can consider maintaining a boost@1.68 bottle in our tap, but I would really not want to do that.

values.title: Visualization of actors in gazebo has friezes if they don’t have skin and there are other moving objects in simulation.

content.raw:
There are very strange friezes in object visualization in gazebo-gui when I use “actors” without skin and there are other moving objects in the simulation. This is quite a weird problem. For quick understanding of it you can watch the attached videos problem.mkv or problem_urdf.mkv. 


Here is some background information:

Not so long ago I had to test some algorithms for a self-driving car and I decided to create a simple gazebo world with citysim as a basis. When I turned citysim on, I saw that all the cars were moving with some friezes but at the same time people were moving smoothly. Firstly, I tried to use a more powerful machine (i7-8700k+GTX1080) to turn on the simulation but the friezes were still there. Then I started cutting the world file until I thought of the circumstances when the friezes appeared. 

They only appeared only in 2 conditions: 

1.	Actors have no skin tag or it is empty – there is only unempty link tag or include tag.

2.	There is another moving object (not actor) added to the simulation. For example I used gazebo model «sckoda prius» or spawn simple ROS urdf file - R2D2.  

Here are some important details: 

1.	The friezes only appear in visualization (gazebo-gui). When I use plot built-in gazebo I see that the position of the box is changing smoothly. Also when I use gazebo_ros_gpu_laser I see a smooth movement of points corresponding to the box in RVIZ. 

2.	Gazebo-gui works approximately on 60 Hz. This means that there are friezes only in some actors.  

3.	The problem appears without the ROS usage (look problem.world). 

4.	The degree of the friezes doesn’t depend on the presence and the type of the measuring sensors but depends only on the number of other moving objects (not actors) and number of links they have. The more powerful the PC is, the more objects there are needed (for example, 10 sckoda prius for i7-8700k+GTX1080). 

For clarity I filmed a couple of simple videos and created two simple worlds (they are attached). Each of them has three actors:

1.	animated_box – there is only link tag

2.	animated_man – there is only skin tag

3.	animated_man_box – there are both link и skin

In the «no_problem.world» there is nothing else and as you can see all three objects are moving smoothly (see no_problem.mkv).
In the «problem.world» there are 5 added sckoda prius objects, which cause the appearance of the friezes in the visualization of the animated_box while animated_man and animated_man_box are moving smoothly. All other added objects are moving smoothly. (see problem*.mkv).

I tested it on: 
Ubuntu 16.04 + i5-6600+GTX1050 + gazebo 9.6 + nvidia 415 
Ubuntu 16.04 + i7-8700k+GTX1080 + gazebo 9.6 + nvidia 384

But when you put "orthographic" it crashes with no error message, but I think it's a segfault if that helps. I even tried saving a world file from the gui and checking that the generated camera code cannot even be loaded.

values.title: Wrong camera projection matrix

content.raw:
# Sensor definition #
I have a camera sensor with intrinsic parameters:
```
#!XML

        <camera>
          <!-- FOV = 2 * arctan(w/(2*f_x)), with f_x = 536.473145060694 -->
          <horizontal_fov>1.0756668597435934</horizontal_fov>
          <image>
            <format>R8G8B8</format>
            <width>640</width>
            <height>480</height>
          </image>
          <clip>
            <near>0.0001</near>
            <far>1000</far>
          </clip>
          <distortion>
            <k1>0.03310900261913022</k1>
            <k2>-0.1081296635444241</k2>
            <p1>0.0003885055533487762</p1>
            <p2>-0.001167055731123937</p2>
            <k3>0</k3>
            <!-- relative centre with c = (314.0086519801989, 246.7391576005324) -->
            <center>0.49063851871906083 0.5140399116677759</center>
          </distortion>
        </camera>
```

# Expected projection matrix #
According to http://www.songho.ca/opengl/gl_projectionmatrix.html#perspective, the projection matrix is:
![opengl_proj.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3911210773-opengl_proj.png)
For the given camera parameters this should be something around:
```
P: 
   1.67648          0  -0.018723          0
         0   -2.23693 -0.0280798          0
         0          0          1    -0.0002
         0          0          1          0
```
The signs are different because this is in a RDF (x - Right, y - Down, z - Front) coordinate system.

# Projection matrix used in camera sensor #
But the projection matrix (`Camera::ProjectionMatrix()`) gives (row-major):
```
1.67647 0 0 0 0 2.2353 0 0 0 0 -1 -0.0002 0 0 -1 0
```
which is missing values for P(0,2) and P(1,2) (they are set to 0).

Since Gazebo 10 I can update the camera intrinsics via `Camera::UpdateCameraIntrinsics`:
```
#!c++

UpdateCameraIntrinsics(536.473145060694, 536.8639285109052, 314.0086519801989, 246.7391576005324, 1.0);
```
or compute the projection matrix manually via `Camera::BuildProjectiveMatrix`:
```
#!c++

BuildProjectiveMatrix(640, 480, 536.473145060694, 536.8639285109052, 314.0086519801989, 246.7391576005324, 1.0, 0.0001, 1000);
```

in which case I get:
```
1.67648 0.003125 0.018723 0 0 2.23693 -0.02808 0 0 0 -1 -0.0002 0 0 -1 0
```
as projection matrix.
This is still not correct since this time P(0,1)=0.003125, which should be 0.

I have a camera sensor with intrinsic parameters:

          <horizontal_fov>1.0756668597435934</horizontal_fov>
          <image>
            <format>R8G8B8</format>
            <width>640</width>
            <height>480</height>
          </image>

values.title: Wrong reference point for optical centre (cx, cy)

content.raw:
It seems, that the optical centre (principal point) of the intrinsic parameters (since Gazebo10) has to be given with respect to the bottom left corner of the image (x=0, y=hight). Usually, the optical centre is given with respect to the image origin (x=0, y=0), that is the top left of an image.


# Setup #
I created a camera sensor (640 x 480) with intrinsic parameters:
```
#!XML
          <lens>
            <intrinsics>
              <fx>536.473145060694</fx>
              <fy>536.8639285109052</fy>
              <cx>314.0086519801989</cx>
              <cy>246.7391576005324</cy>
              <s>0</s>
            </intrinsics>
          </lens>
```
and a box centred inside the optical frame with 0.5m distance for demonstration purpose:
```
#!XML
      <visual name="visual">
        <pose>0.5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <box>
            <size>0.1 0.1 0.1</size>
          </box>
        </geometry>
        <material>
          <ambient>0.1 0.1 0.1 1</ambient>
          <diffuse>0.1 0.1 0.2 1</diffuse>
          <specular>0 0 0 0</specular>
          <emissive>0 0 0 1</emissive>
        </material>
      </visual>
```

# Result #
The rendered image
![image.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3744898896-image.png)
shows a rectangular shape with approx. 120x120pxl dimension. The upper left coordinate of the rectangle is (x=254, y=173) and the lower right is (x=373, y=293).

If you compute the centre of the rectangle in the image plane, you get cx=254+60=314, which matches with the given cx=314, and cy=173+60=233, which does not match with the given cy=246.

I turns out, that the optical centre (cx,cy) is expected relative to the bottom left. I.e. if I change cy=480−246.734=233.26 the rectangular shape is correctly centred at the optical centre (314, 246).
content.html:
It seems, that the optical centre (principal point) of the intrinsic parameters (since Gazebo10) has to be given with respect to the bottom left corner of the image (x=0, y=hight). Usually, the optical centre is given with respect to the image origin (x=0, y=0), that is the top left of an image.

Setup

I created a camera sensor (640 x 480) with intrinsic parameters:

          <lens>
            <intrinsics>
              <fx>536.473145060694</fx>
              <fy>536.8639285109052</fy>
              <cx>314.0086519801989</cx>
              <cy>246.7391576005324</cy>
              <s>0</s>
            </intrinsics>
          </lens>

and a box centred inside the optical frame with 0.5m distance for demonstration purpose:

      <visual name="visual">
        <pose>0.5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <box>
            <size>0.1 0.1 0.1</size>
          </box>
        </geometry>
        <material>
          <ambient>0.1 0.1 0.1 1</ambient>
          <diffuse>0.1 0.1 0.2 1</diffuse>
          <specular>0 0 0 0</specular>
          <emissive>0 0 0 1</emissive>
        </material>
      </visual>

Result

The rendered image shows a rectangular shape with approx. 120x120pxl dimension. The upper left coordinate of the rectangle is (x=254, y=173) and the lower right is (x=373, y=293).

If you compute the centre of the rectangle in the image plane, you get cx=254+60=314, which matches with the given cx=314, and cy=173+60=233, which does not match with the given cy=246.

I turns out, that the optical centre (cx,cy) is expected relative to the bottom left. I.e. if I change cy=480−246.734=233.26 the rectangular shape is correctly centred at the optical centre (314, 246).

values.title: URDF to SDF conversions ignores links with no visual

content.raw:
When converting a URDF via `gz sdf -p robot.urdf > robot.sdf` to SDF, links with no visual element get removed / are ignored.

Converting the attached URDF (source: robotiq 3finger [xacro](https://github.com/ros-industrial/robotiq/tree/kinetic-devel/robotiq_3f_gripper_visualization/cfg)) via
`gz sdf -p robotiq-3f-gripper_articulated.urdf > robotiq-3f-gripper_articulated.sdf` results in the attached SDF.

While the URDF contains the link **tool0** (`<link name="tool0"/>`), the exported SDF is missing this link. This also effects the spawning of URDF models via the ROS plugin.
I guess this also breaks the kinematic tree in general. E.g. Gazebo cannot spawn models that have an "invisible" link in their kinematic chain.

Since this link is not part of the kinematic chain, it cannot be used as reference for spawning other models. This is however important if models are to be spawn relative to "invisible" links, like grasp links that are commonly used for grippers.
content.html:
When converting a URDF via gz sdf -p robot.urdf > robot.sdf to SDF, links with no visual element get removed / are ignored.

Converting the attached URDF (source: robotiq 3finger xacro) via gz sdf -p robotiq-3f-gripper_articulated.urdf > robotiq-3f-gripper_articulated.sdf results in the attached SDF.

While the URDF contains the link tool0 (<link name="tool0"/>), the exported SDF is missing this link. This also effects the spawning of URDF models via the ROS plugin. I guess this also breaks the kinematic tree in general. E.g. Gazebo cannot spawn models that have an "invisible" link in their kinematic chain.

Since this link is not part of the kinematic chain, it cannot be used as reference for spawning other models. This is however important if models are to be spawn relative to "invisible" links, like grasp links that are commonly used for grippers.

values.title: Gazebo unstable and crashing

content.raw:
Hello List,

I have a (now simplified) model of a rower in a boat that keeps crashing or is very unstable.
The code can be found in my  [github](https://github.com/SietseAchterop/Rowing).

See the model in the file [boot.xacro](https://github.com/SietseAchterop/Rowing/blob/master/boot3_description/urdf/boot.xacro).
There also is a boot.sdf that is generated from that, with only the ros_plugin removed so it can directly be run in gazebo.

Starting this model most of the time shows a wildly unstable behaviour, see this [video](https://github.com/SietseAchterop/Rowing/blob/master/unstable_rower.mp4).

If I change the shoulder joint to have 3 instead of 2 revolute joints, then the model crashes immediately, see this [video](https://github.com/SietseAchterop/Rowing/blob/master/unstable_3_shoulder_joints.mp4).

I cannot find anything wrong with the model, all masses, inertias etc. are sane, so I only can conclude there is a bug here.

values.title: Simulation Time Management

content.raw:
One of Gazebo's primary limitations its inflexible manner of dealing with simulation time.  In its current implementation, Gazebo relies on the physics engine to drive time, which has a number of issues:

1. **Sensors are not able to coordinate with the physics engine to render at the desired rate.** For example, a user may want a camera to render at 60 fps.  However, the hardware may only enable an average render rate of 20 fps.  Thus, in order to prevent frame loss, the user must slow down the physics simulation to a fixed rate which reflects the highest possible render time per frame much lower than 20 fps.  A pull request was made a while ago to fix this issue:
#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2502/make-sure-cameras-fps-is-strictly-applied/diff

2. **Simulations cannot run as fast as possible without coordination issues.** Faster-than-real-time simulation is a desired feature for automated testing, regression testing, and reinforcement learning.  In order to properly enable faster-than-real-time, the physics engine and sensor manager must coordinate so that event and render timings are accurate, which goes back to issue 1.  In addition, the simulation must allow coordinating time with an external entity, which represents simulation components outside of Gazebo (ex. ROS nodes in a simulation should be able block simulation time to enforce their update rates).  If Gazebo's time cannot be externally driven, then a faster-than-real-time simulation may create a chain of events with temporally incorrect causality.  For example, the rate of processing of sensor input in the simulation may not reflect the real world.

3. **Gazebo may not be able to interact with external simulation components.**  Users may want to add additional simulation components outside of Gazebo.  However, there is currently no way to coordinate time with external components.


I was hoping to be able to work on adding time management features to Gazebo, which may involve the addition of new fundamental classes and an overhaul of how Gazebo is set up and run.  Concretely, these features are:
1. Adding modes of driving time, including:
  a. A mode that reflects the current way time is run (by the physics engine)
  b. A mode that enables faster-than-real-time and time coordination between the physics engine, sensor manager and external entity
2. An external api of some kind that allows the external entity to coordinate with Gazebo's time

content.raw:
I am just trying to make a map and navigate it in the Gazebo. I am running Ubuntu 15.10 and ROS Kinetic. I run these in separate terminal windows:


```
#!c++

roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_world.launch

roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo gmapping_demo.launch

roslaunch turtlebot_rviz_launchers view_navigation.launch

roslaunch kobuki_keyop keyop.launch

#!c++

[ WARN] [1550005269.894992827]: KeyOp: could not connect, trying again after 500ms...
[ERROR] [1550005270.400225747]: KeyOp: could not connect.
[ERROR] [1550005270.400604286]: KeyOp: check remappings for enable/disable topics).

```
I then check the roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_world.launch terminal window, and see the following error:


```
#!c++
gzserver: /build/ogre-1.9-VJX7tp/ogre-1.9-1.9.0+dfsg1/OgreMain/src/OgreRenderSystem.cpp:546: virtual void Ogre::RenderSystem::setDepthBufferFor(Ogre::RenderTarget*): Assertion `bAttached && "A new DepthBuffer for a RenderTarget was created, but after creation" "it says it's incompatible with that RT"' failed.

I used the model editor to compose a model with two different models I had and a fixed link between them. Then, when launching the world it doesn't publish their links in the topic.

I think that when in the sdf file the model is composed by more models inside, the topic is not displaying those links.

values.title: Material transparency doesn't work on Gazebo 9

content.html:
I've defined gazebo materials with transparency for a URDF model. E.g.

material MyMaterial
{
  technique
  {
    pass ambient
    {
      ambient 0.698 0.698 0.698 0.9
      diffuse 0.698 0.698 0.698 0.9
      specular 0.2 0.2 0.2 0.9
    }
  }
}

When loading the model on gazebo 7, the relevant links appear transparent. The same doesn't happen on gazebo 9 (v9.6.0). The meshes used are stl files.

values.title: Add method to check if link was initialized?

content.html:
The Link class has a protected bool "initialized", but there is no way to query it (its only used by inherited classes, so it seems). Would it be useful to add a public bool getInitialized() const or bool isInitialized() const to the class, similar to the bool GetEnabled() const?

My use case is this:

I don't want to add the example actor collision plugin to all my actors / world files.

You don't really need the plugin if you don't need to scale or adjust pose of the collision bodies (which is odd to do in the plugin anyway? it seems like the plugin corrects for a poor specification in the actor model itself, right?). The only thing you need to do is call this once per actor:

if (model->HasType(gazebo::physics::Base::EntityType::ACTOR) {
    // by calling the actor's canonical link, all children should become initialized as well I think?
    model->GetLink("canonical")->Init();
}

Now I'm checking for objects on every ConnectWorldUpdateBegin event callback. So I'm concerned to run the Init every time, as the implementation seems costly (especially considering I have several tens of actors based on the CitySim world).

I tried to find a way if I can see if the links are already initialized, but there really seems no way. I tried if I could tell using a try/catch, but I haven't found any illegal call that gives me something catchable that will tell me to Init the actor links.

By the way, you could also consider making the init call cheaper by having it check if "initialized == true" and if yes, return immediately, rather than running init again. I'm not sure if this might break any use cases in which a re-init is needed? In that case, you could adjust it to be a void Init(bool force_reinit = true), such that no existing code breaks?

Lastly: why are actor links not initialized by default? is it considered too costly? Does it impact the physics engine a lot to have "collidable" actors? In that case, wouldn't it be an idea to have a SDF element for the actor that sets "collidable" to true or false?

And wouldn't you agree that the scaling of collision bodies is not a proper 'after the fact' fix, it should be correct in the model itself right? Now if you scale collision bodies using the example plugin, Gazebo GUI still renders unscaled collision bodies (if you enabled collision bodies from the View menu).

values.title: Mal-formed pkgconfig file

content.raw:
Gazebo's gazebo.pc.in pkg-config LIBS field contains a placeholder for `@Boost_PKGCONFIG_LIBS@`.  That CMake variable is assembled in the root CMakeLists.txt, with some string processing that unconditionally prepends `-l` to each entry in `Boost_LIBRARIES`.

[In Fedora 30](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1680265), the `Boost_LIBRARIES` CMake variable contains `-lpthread` in addition to the absolute paths to the required boost libraries.  The string processing in CMakeLists.txt adds an additional `-l` in front of it, resulting in `-l-lpthread` being added to the LIBS line.  Fedora 30 has Boost 1.69.0, and CMake 3.13.4

[This patch](https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/gazebo/blob/master/f/gazebo-9.5.0-pkgconfig.patch) works around the issue by checking each string to see if `-l` is already pre-pended to the string.  There's probably some extra thought that can be put into this section, such as only eliminating `lib` from the front of the library name, and performing no additional processing if `-l` is detected, but the referenced patch is enough to work around the Fedora 30 issue.

In Fedora 30, the Boost_LIBRARIES CMake variable contains -lpthread in addition to the absolute paths to the required boost libraries. The string processing in CMakeLists.txt adds an additional -l in front of it, resulting in -l-lpthread being added to the LIBS line. Fedora 30 has Boost 1.69.0, and CMake 3.13.4

This patch works around the issue by checking each string to see if -l is already pre-pended to the string. There's probably some extra thought that can be put into this section, such as only eliminating lib from the front of the library name, and performing no additional processing if -l is detected, but the referenced patch is enough to work around the Fedora 30 issue.
